french.description_en: Learn essential French greetings and how to introduce yourself.
french.tip_en: In French, 'bonjour' (hello) is used until evening, then switch to 'bonsoir' (good evening). Always use 'vous' (formal) with strangers!

french.description_en: Count in French from one to a thousand.
french.tip_en: French numbers 70‚Äì99 are tricky! 70 = soixante-dix (sixty-ten), 80 = quatre-vingts (four-twenties), 90 = quatre-vingt-dix (four-twenty-ten).

french.description_en: Learn colors and how to describe things in French.
french.tip_en: Adjectives in French usually come AFTER the noun: 'une robe rouge' (a red dress). Exceptions: grand, petit, beau, nouveau come BEFORE.

french.title_lang: Les Jours, le Temps et les Saisons
french.description_en: Talk about days of the week, time expressions, and seasons.
french.tip_en: Days of the week are NOT capitalized in French: lundi, mardi... Same for months: janvier, f√©vrier...

french.tip_en: To say 'my father' use 'mon p√®re' (masculine), 'my mother' = 'ma m√®re' (feminine). Possessives agree with the noun, not the owner!

french.tip_en: To say something hurts: 'J'ai mal √† + body part' ‚Üí J'ai mal √† la t√™te (I have a headache). Very useful at the doctor!

french.tip_en: At a French caf√©: 'Je voudrais...' (I would like...) is polite. 'Je prends...' (I'll have...) is common. Always say 'Monsieur/Madame' to get attention!

french.tip_en: In Paris, the metro is called 'le m√©tro'. Ask: 'Excusez-moi, o√π est le m√©tro?' or 'Pour aller √†...?' (How do I get to...?)

french.tip_en: √ätre (to be) and Avoir (to have) are the two most important verbs. They are irregular but used in almost every sentence!

french.description_en: Describe people, places, and things using French adjectives.
french.tip_en: Adjectives must agree with the noun in gender and number. Add -e for feminine, -s for plural: grand ‚Üí grande ‚Üí grands ‚Üí grandes.

french.title_lang: Grammaire : Les Articles et le Genre
french.description_en: Understand French noun gender and definite/indefinite articles.

grammar.intro_en: Every French noun has a gender ‚Äî masculine (m) or feminine (f). This is different from Bengali or English! You MUST memorize the gender with each word.

sections.note_en: Use 'le' for masculine nouns, 'la' for feminine, 'l'' before vowels, and 'les' for all plurals.

french.description_en: Conjugate regular and common irregular verbs in the present tense.

grammar.intro_en: French verbs must change form (conjugate) depending on who is doing the action. There are 3 types of regular verbs: -er, -ir, -re. The most common is -er.

sections.note_en: Remove -er and add: -e, -es, -e, -ons, -ez, -ent. Note: je/tu/il/elle/ils/elles endings all sound the same (-e, -es, -ent are all silent)!
√äTRE is completely irregular ‚Äî memorize each form! 'Je suis √©tudiant' (I am a student). Very important for introducing yourself.
'J'ai 25 ans' = I am 25 years old (lit: I have 25 years). In French you 'have' an age, not 'are' an age!

spanish.tip_en: Spanish greetings change by time of day: 'Buenos d√≠as' (morning), 'Buenas tardes' (afternoon), 'Buenas noches' (night). In Spain, friends often kiss on both cheeks!

spanish.description_en: Learn colors and how to describe things in Spanish.
spanish.tip_en: Like French, Spanish adjectives come AFTER the noun: 'una casa roja' (a red house). Colors also agree with gender: rojo (m) / roja (f), azul stays the same for both.

spanish.title_lang: Los D√≠as, el Tiempo y las Estaciones
spanish.description_en: Talk about days of the week, time, and seasons in Spanish.
spanish.tip_en: In Spanish, 'ma√±ana' can mean both 'tomorrow' AND 'morning'. Context helps: 'ma√±ana por la ma√±ana' = tomorrow morning.

spanish.description_en: Describe your family members and talk about relationships.
spanish.tip_en: 'Mi familia es muy importante para m√≠' (My family is very important to me). Use 'tengo' (I have) to talk about family: 'Tengo un hermano' (I have a brother).

spanish.description_en: Learn body parts and describe health issues in Spanish.
spanish.tip_en: To say something hurts: 'Me duele + body part' ‚Üí 'Me duele la cabeza' (My head hurts). For plural: 'Me duelen los pies' (My feet hurt).

spanish.description_en: Order food and navigate a Spanish menu with confidence.
spanish.tip_en: In Spanish restaurants: lunch (la comida) is the main meal at 2-3pm! 'Quisiera...' (I would like...) is polite. Ask for 'la cuenta' (the bill) when done.

spanish.tip_en: Ask directions: '¬øC√≥mo llego a...?' (How do I get to...?). Directions: recto/todo recto (straight), a la derecha (right), a la izquierda (left), gira (turn).

spanish.description_en: Master the most important Spanish verbs for daily conversation.
spanish.tip_en: SER vs ESTAR is the hardest concept for Spanish learners! SER = permanent identity (Soy m√©dico). ESTAR = temporary state (Estoy cansado). Practice both every day!

spanish.description_en: Describe people, places, and things using Spanish adjectives.
spanish.tip_en: Adjectives agree with nouns: grande (big) stays grande for all, but bonito (m) ‚Üí bonita (f). Most -o adjectives become -a for feminine.

spanish.description_en: Master the two Spanish verbs meaning 'to be' ‚Äî the most important distinction in Spanish!

grammar.intro_en: Spanish has TWO verbs meaning 'to be': SER (permanent/inherent) and ESTAR (temporary/changeable). This has NO equivalent in Bengali ‚Äî it's a uniquely Spanish challenge!

grammar.intro_en: Spanish verbs end in -ar, -er, or -ir. Each type has its own set of endings in the present tense. The good news: -er and -ir are almost the same!
